title: [Large-Scale] Bridge Computer-Aided Design Education Utilizing Flipped Learning and Collaborative Problem-Based Learning

context.prior_knowledge: Basic engineering mathematics and CAD software experience
context.additional_context: Curriculum integrating flipped learning with collaborative problem-based learning (CPBL) for bridge design projects in a digital device-enabled environment

learning_goals: Learners can mathematically model fundamental bridge design principles and implement them using CAD tools.

Learners can analyze three real-world engineering problems (e.g., bridge design, fluid dynamics simulation, structural vibration analysis) through six months of collaborative problem-based learning (CPBL), apply a five-stage design process (problem definition → idea generation → prototyping → testing → improvement) per team, write a final report, and pass the presentation evaluation by scoring over 80 points based on the rubric (problem-solving completeness 30%, creativity 20%, team collaboration 20%, report clarity 15%, presentation delivery 15%).

Learners can set self-directed learning plans at least twice weekly over four weeks in a flipped learning environment using provided video lectures (8) and materials, achieve over 80% accuracy on weekly quizzes (5 questions), and submit a final project report for performance evaluation.
difficulty: Hard - Complex requirements with multiple constraints
